intro.p: Use the two scatter plots and the given information about the regression models to answer the questions below.

content.p: Which model, if any, would you use to predict the price of a car? Explain why your choice would be the best model to get an accurate prediction.

outtro.p: MSRP vs HP is the better model to make predictions with. To explain which regression model is better, there are several options. One is to look at which has a stronger correlation, R. Note that "stronger" refers to being closer to 1 or -1. The closer a correlation is to 1 or -1, the stronger it is. Conversely, the closer to 0 a correlation is, the weaker it is. Another option is to look at R-squared. Because R is the square root of R-squared, a stronger R is the same as having the higher R-squared. Finally, if for some reason you don't actually know what R or R-squared are, you can look at the graph to see which model has the dots on the scatterplot more packed together into a line. In this case, the R-squared (R^2) value is higher for MSRP vs HP when compared to the one for MSRP vs Engine size. This means that the correlation coefficient, R, for MSRP vs HP is closer to either 1 or -1 when compared to the correlation coefficient for MSRP vs Engine size. In order to explain your answers for this standard, it is important to put all your answers into the real world context of the problem.

content.p: Would you use one of the regression models to predict the MSRP of a vehicle with an engine size of 3.2 liters? Why or why not?

outtro.p: No, the model has a weak correlation. Remember that there are two reasons NOT to use a regression model. Either the correlation is too weak (usually something under 0.4) or the value for which you are trying to make a prediction is outside the range of the data. Note - this does NOT mean that it is outside the range of the GRAPH. It is possible to have a value that is in the range of the graph (if you have a long axis) but that is still outside the range of the DATA. In this case, the correlation is well below 0.4 so that is the main reason.

outtro.p: A specific car in the dataset with {{point_4x}} horsepower and a MSRP of ${{point_4y}}. Dots on a scatterplot represent individuals in the dataset. In this case, the dataset is made up of cars. The values on the scatterplot are two quantitative values about ONE car. So on the MSRP vs horsepower graph it is the MSRP and horsepower of a specific car. For the MSRP vs Engine Size graph it is the MSRP and Engine Size of a specific car.
